message_1: What is the range of the equation y = |x - 2| + 3?
message_2:
The range of a function is the set of all possible output values (y-values) that the function can produce. In this case, the function is y = |x - 2| + 3.

The absolute value function, |x - 2|, will always produce a non-negative value, since it represents the distance between x and 2 on the number line. The smallest value it can produce is 0, which occurs when x = 2.

Now, let's consider the entire function y = |x - 2| + 3. Since the absolute value part is always non-negative, the smallest value for y occurs when the absolute value part is 0. In this case, y = 0 + 3 = 3.

As x moves away from 2, the absolute value part will increase, and so will the value of y. There is no upper bound on how large y can become, as the absolute value part can grow indefinitely.
